div1.p: Williams discusses the value of money in relation to the work in the Public Health Service.

div1.head: Letter from Louis L. Williams, Jr., to Henry Rose Carter, January 29, 1920
div1.opener:
L L Williams, Jr.
P. A. Surg U.S. Public Health Service
Miscl
Salaries
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
ROOM 211
289 MAIN ST.
SPRINGFIELD, MASS.
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Jan. 29, 1920.
Regulation
Dear Dr. Carter.
div1.p:
Altho my reply to your letter of Dec. 31, last, is
somewhat delayed. I am none the less appreciative of the same. Your
position is entirely clear; and, as usual, follow your ideals. I have
always been glad of all oportunities to observe your method of
thought and reasoning, and am not unmindful of the honor you do me
in sending me your letter to Dr. Noland with comments. In the main
I am compelled to agree with you, and to at least admit that on the
bassis that you take that your reasoning is unassailable. You have
ever held that, “The work is the thing”, and that all else should be
subordinated to that end. True, and on that line of reasoning, it is
unnecessary to pay large salaries to higher officers; they should do
their work to their highest ability and not necessasarily expect to
receive enormous salaries, a living wage only.

In my day in Charlottsville there was a shoe maker
who did all the cobbling for the University students, whose name was
Apple. He held a degree of B.A. from Yale, had fallen on hard times,
become a shoe maker and somewhat of a philosepher----doubtless
to fill up the tedium of his mechanical work, thought not being an
essential in the fitting of a new sole. He was a very entertaining
talker and we often listened to him discourse at length. Some of
his sayings had a way of “sticking”. I can remember taking to him
a shoe that needed one tack to hold a shoe plate that aws was falling
off. Shoe makers do not usually charge for such small things. He
charged me one cent, remarking with a smile. “The laborer is worthy
of his hire”. He gravely handed me four cents from the nickle I handed
him and resumed his work. The little quotation stuck. And this is,
I think, a premise that you do not take into consideration at all.
For the laborer is worthy of his hire and should be payed somewhat
in accordance thereoff.

Of course the younger men of the Service need more
pay---they are almost in want; I'm not so shure that many of the older
men are not nearly as bad off. Consider my Dad for instance---he is
in no sence a spendthrift; he sent his boys to college commencing in
1907---to allow them to finish he had to borrow extensively--with
the purchase of his last Liberty Bond in 1918 his assets (as represen-
ted by these bonds) exceeded what he yet owed on his debts from our
college days by only three hundred dollars---eleven years later!
Should not a man who has attained the age sufficient to have grown
children receive enough to enable him to educate them without having
to go so extensively into debt. Have you any doubt that you could have
gone with some large corporation and now be drawing in excess of
twenty five thousand dollars a year---I have no doubt of it. The work
you have done for this country in quarantine, in yellow fever, in malaria
have been as valuable to the nation as an equal amount would have
been to some private enterprise & more, and they would have paid you many
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
times as much. Why should you maintain that you should not receive
over five thousand because you can live on that sum instead of fifty
thousand because you earn it? Is not the laborer worthy of his hire?"
Suppose you had not been blessed with such a child as Laura is?
Could you have afforded to hire (on your pay) a secretary? Without
a secretary how much of your last ten years of writings could have
been done? Even your modesty will not permitt you to think that
these have not been of the greatest value. Had you been a lesser man
cuold you have mantained the high rate of working production with all
the family trouble that has been yours? Had your pay been double would
it not have eased the path---cuold you not have attended to Edward
without such a strain---would your mind not be easier in regard to
what you could leave your daughter? If a man's mind is easy on his
financial side his work is better (perhaps it ought not be affected,
but it is). And so I most respectfully but firmly submit that I do
truly believe that the laborer is indeed worthy of his hire and should
receive a good proportion of it.

It also seems to me that one reason that we are loosing
so many of our good men is that they see no very great monetary reward
in the Service and cast their eye toward the industrial world. I do
not mean by this that I think that the Service should offer twenty
thousand dollar salaries, (some would earn them, many more would not),
for a good man takes much of his remunaration not in money but in
an increased oportunity to do his work in an ever widening field, and
much of it in the realization of good work well done--and not a little
of it in the doing of his work----never-the-less, he should not be
expected to take too much of his reward in an internall feeling. Even
the higher grades should receive much more than at present.

I do not believe that I have bored you for my statement
has been frank and earnest. If you believe me to be too mercenary
or otherwise missguided I know you will honor me by saying so and
in taking the trouble to point out to me wherin and why you dissagree.

With affectionate regards to you and all the family from
both Gertrude and myself I remain as ever
